Massachusetts General Laws, c. 186, \u00.proposition: This is a civil action to recover damages caused by the Defendant's breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws, c. 186, § 14, which protects tenants from substantial interference with their rental premises.

M.G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to M.G.L. c. 218, § 19 since the damages sought are within the monetary limits of this Court.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is appropriate pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, § 2, as the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Dorchester, within this Court's jurisdiction.

M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant’s failure to provide adequate heating constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Premises, in violation of M.G.L. c. 186, § 14 and common law.

*Armstrong v. Botsaris*, 20 Mass. App. C.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently upheld tenants' rights to relief for landlords' failure to provide habitable conditions, including in *Armstrong v. Botsaris*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 503 (1985); *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); and *Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Industries, Inc.*, 427 Mass. 1 (1998), which acknowledge substantial interference with use and enjoyment as actionable under Massachusetts law.
*Armstrong v. Botsaris*, 20 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about conspiracy to violate Massachusetts conflict-of-interest statutes involving county officials; it does not involve landlord-tenant law, the warranty of habitability, or tenants’ rights to habitable conditions. There is no discussion of substantial interference with use and enjoyment of leased premises or any landlord obligations. Thus, citing Armstrong v. Botsaris, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 503 (1985), for tenant habitability rights misrepresents its holding and context.
*Armstrong v. Botsaris*, 20 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: “It was the Commonwealth’s theory at trial that Burke, while an Essex County commissioner, and Gaudet, an assistant county dog officer, entered into a conspiracy with the other persons named in the indictments. The purpose of the conspiracy was for Burke and Gaudet to solicit and receive money the guise of campaign contributions in return for Burke’s being influenced in an official act, i.e., the award to Project Construction Management, Inc. (PCM), of construction management contracts for certain projects contemplated by Essex County.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently upheld tenants' rights to relief for landlords' failure to provide habitable conditions, including in *Armstrong v. Botsaris*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 503 (1985); *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); and *Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Industries, Inc.*, 427 Mass. 1 (1998), which acknowledge substantial interference with use and enjoyment as actionable under Massachusetts law.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes and applies Massachusetts tenants’ rights to relief for a landlord’s failure to maintain habitable conditions and to avoid substantial interference with use and enjoyment. The court reaffirms the implied warranty of habitability (with reference to Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway and Crowell v. McCaffrey) and holds the landlord liable for flooding conditions that violated the sanitary code, interfered with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c.186 §14, and caused compensable personal and emotional injuries. This fits the proposition that substantial interference with use and enjoyment is actionable under Massachusetts law.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “We have held that every landlord that rents residential property warrants to its tenants that the premises will be delivered and maintained in a habitable condition…. Further, a landlord that fails to maintain a habitable dwelling for its tenant is liable for resulting personal injuries, at least when the landlord has failed to exercise reasonable care in maintenance.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Industries, In.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently upheld tenants' rights to relief for landlords' failure to provide habitable conditions, including in *Armstrong v. Botsaris*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 503 (1985); *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); and *Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Industries, Inc.*, 427 Mass. 1 (1998), which acknowledge substantial interference with use and enjoyment as actionable under Massachusetts law.
*Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Industries, In.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns Massachusetts landlord–tenant law and tenants’ rights to relief for failure to provide habitable conditions and substantial interference with use and enjoyment. Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Industries, Inc. is an employment handicap-discrimination case under G.L. c. 151B and workers’ compensation law, not a residential tenancy or warranty of habitability case. It neither discusses landlords, tenants, habitability, nor interference with use and enjoyment of leased premises, so it does not support the proposition cited.
*Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Industries, In.relevant_excerpt: We clarify today the prima facie standard a plaintiff must meet to establish liability in a case involving a claim of handicap discrimination in violation of G. L. c. 151B, § 4 (16). The defendant, Browning-Ferris Industries, Inc. (Mass.) (BFI), appeals from a jury verdict that it unlawfully fired the plaintiff, Brian A. Dartt, because of a handicap, an earlier work-related injury to his back.
